original.devanagari:
अन्यदेवाहुर्विद्यया अन्यदाहुरविद्यया ।
इति शुश्रुम धीराणां ये नस्तद्विचचक्षिरे ॥ १० ॥
original.iast:
anyad evāhur vidyayā anyad āhur avidyayā |
iti śuśruma dhīrāṇāṃ ye nas tad vicacakṣire || 10 ||

translations.text: Different indeed, they say, is the result from vidyā (knowledge); different, they say, is the result from avidyā (karma). Thus have we heard from the wise who explained that to us.
Different, indeed, they say, is (the result) from knowledge; and different, they say, is (the result) from ignorance. Thus have we heard from the wise who explained it to us.

bhashya.sanskrit:
अन्यत् पृथगेव विद्यया क्रियते फलमिति आहुः वदन्ति, अन्यदाहुरविद्यया कर्मणा क्रियते फलमिति । तथोक्तम् — 'कर्मणा पितृलोकः, विद्यया देवलोकः' (बृ. उ. १ । ५ । १६) इति । इति एवं शुश्रुम श्रुतवन्तो वयं धीराणां धीमतां वचनम् । ये आचार्या नः अस्मभ्यं तत् कर्म च ज्ञानं च विचचक्षिरे व्याख्यातवन्तः, तेषामयमागमः पारम्पर्यागत इत्यर्थः ॥ 

यत एवमतः —
keyPoints: Vidyā produces a different result than avidyā (karma)
As stated in Bṛhadāraṇyaka: 'By karma, pitṛ-loka; by vidyā, deva-loka'
This teaching comes from the wise (dhīra), meaning teachers
It is received through paramparā (traditional lineage)
The ācāryas have explained both karma and jñāna to us
This establishes the separate fruits of vidyā and avidyā, justifying their combination
The different results prove neither should be abandoned
bhashya.notes: This mantra establishes that vidyā (deity-knowledge/upāsanā) and avidyā (karma) produce different results, which is the basis for their combination. Śaṅkara Bhagavadpāda cites Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.5.16 as scriptural authority: karma leads to pitṛ-loka (world of ancestors), while vidyā leads to deva-loka (world of gods). The mantra emphasizes that this is traditional knowledge received from wise teachers through paramparā, not a new teaching. Since both have distinct, valid fruits mentioned in śruti, both should be practiced together by qualified householders, not abandoned.

centralTeaching: Vidyā (knowledge of deities) and avidyā (karma/rituals) produce different results according to the wise teachers of the tradition. This difference in fruits is the reason why both should be combined, not practiced exclusively - each leads to its own valid goal as per the śāstras.

coreConcepts.definition: The wise ones, referring to ācāryas and teachers in the traditional lineage who transmit Vedic knowledge
Traditional lineage, unbroken succession of teachers; the authentic transmission of knowledge
World of ancestors/manes, attained through karma (rituals)
World of gods/celestials, attained through vidyā (deity-meditation)

relatedVerses.note: Condemned exclusive practice of either; this verse explains why combination is needed
Explains how to combine both - crossing death with avidyā, attaining immortality with vidyā
Source for the different results: karma leads to pitṛ-loka, vidyā to deva-loka
